dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A listener writes in, 'My team constantly starts new things but never finishes the old ones. How do we actually close out a project properly?'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A listener writes in, 'My team constantly starts new things but never finishes the old ones. How do we actually close out a project properly?'

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that is such a common problem. The text mentions Murphy's Law, you know, that things will probably go even worse than you can imagine, which is why a checklist is so crucial.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that is such a common problem. The text mentions Murphy's Law, you know, that things will probably go even worse than you can imagine, which is why a checklist is so crucial.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Murphys law states, Anything that can go wrong will go wrong! In order to avoid a train of challenges arriving during the last stage of your project, it is important to develop a final checklist.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it's not just any checklist—it's one for your team, not just the work itself. They recommend using the 3-W method.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it's not just any checklist-it's one for your team, not just the work itself. They recommend using the three-W method.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Preparing the closeout checklist for your work with an eye to completing all your contractual and project obligations with a very clear deadline will help you to tie up all the loose ends and bypass loopholes and hiccups. The 3-W approach can be very helpful for working on your checklist, as you list the three major W-questions: What [what the most strategically important objectives of the project were and what you achieved to address these], Where [where were the most pressing challenges and if you addressed all of them], and When [when you should achieve your major benchmarks in working on your project and if you realized all your deliverables].

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: The what, where, and when, right? Like, what wasn't achieved, where mistakes happened, and if the timing was off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The what, where, and when, right? Like, what wasn't achieved, where mistakes happened, and if the timing was off.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The 3-W approach can be very helpful for working on your checklist, as you list the three major W-questions: What [what the most strategically important objectives of the project were and what you achieved to address these], Where [where were the most pressing challenges and if you addressed all of them], and When [when you should achieve your major benchmarks in working on your project and if you realized all your deliverables].

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then there's the communication part. You have to be really strategic about who you tell about the project's closure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And then there's the communication part. You have to be really strategic about who you tell about the project's closure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From the long-term planning perspective, it is imperative that all your partners, clients, stakeholders, investors and supporters know about the successful closure of the project and about your achievements along the way.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, not every single stakeholder needs a detailed report, especially for something like a final marketing plan or an app. But an angry customer who gets no notification? That's a nightmare scenario.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, not every single stakeholder needs a detailed report, especially for something like a final marketing plan or an app. But an angry customer who gets no notification? That's a nightmare scenario.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nobody wants an angry customer or especially an investor to pop up at the last moment, unaware that you have already closed the project but forgot to inform her/him and thus technically did not complete all requirements.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. So building that communication strategy is key, but only if there's a publicity requirement. It doesn't include partners otherwise.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. So building that communication strategy is key, but only if there's a publicity requirement. It doesn't include partners otherwise.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From the long-term planning perspective, it is imperative that all your partners, clients, stakeholders, investors and supporters know about the successful closure of the project and about your achievements along the way. And it is certainly important to communicate the information about outcomes as per your contractual obligations, especially if there is a publicity requirement in your project.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then, you know, the text suggests presenting your achievements, maybe at a small private dinner with stakeholders.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then, you know, the text suggests presenting your achievements, maybe at a small private dinner with stakeholders.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Effective project managers always personally present the main achievements of their completed project to all their current and potential partners and clients in a public event or even a series of public events.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Though these days, with the pandemic, online B2B presentations have really taken off as the most effective tool.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though these days, with the pandemic, online B2B presentations have really taken off as the most effective tool.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Paradoxically, the old traditional ways of B2B personalized presentations or lately even online B2B presentations have not gone out of fashion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But it warns against using professional pages like LinkedIn or ResearchGate to store your results. You gotta use proper databases instead.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it warns against using professional pages like LinkedIn or ResearchGate to store your results. You gotta use proper databases instead.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Currently cyberspace offers many opportunities from professionally run databases and data banks related to different fields to personal professional pages (e.g., LinkedIn, ResearchGate, etc.) where you can store information, reports and research data about past and present projects.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then finally, the post-project evaluation. It says post-mortems aren't that important unless the project was extremely long.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then finally, the post-project evaluation. It says post-mortems aren't that important unless the project was extremely long.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Every textbook on project management highlights the importance of post-mortem evaluations. This step can take many forms from formal reports, to memos on lessons learned and even step-by-step evaluation of every failure or mistake, depending on the duration and scale of your project.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I found that part interesting—it says to celebrate the closure with a meeting, but then focus on the negatives, the darkest side of the experience.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I found that part interesting-it says to celebrate the closure with a meeting, but then focus on the negatives, the darkest side of the experience.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thus, even if your project faced many challenges and problems you should focus on the bright side of your experience in the project, creating links to life after this project or transitioning to the next ones.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, quoting Dwight Eisenhower, that optimism never won any battle. So you analyze what went wrong before even thinking about future projects.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, quoting Dwight Eisenhower, that optimism never won any battle. So you analyze what went wrong before even thinking about future projects.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pessimism never won any battle, Dwight Eisenhower famously said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's a pretty pragmatic, almost pessimistic approach to wrapping things up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a pretty pragmatic, almost pessimistic approach to wrapping things up.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But maybe that's what it takes to actually finish strong and learn from it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But maybe that's what it takes to actually finish strong and learn from it.

artist_script:
HostA: A listener writes in, 'My team constantly starts new things but never finishes the old ones. How do we actually close out a project properly?'
HostB: Oh, that is such a common problem. The text mentions Murphy's Law, you know, that things will probably go even worse than you can imagine, which is why a checklist is so crucial.
HostA: Right, and it’s not just any checklist—it's one for your team, not just the work itself. They recommend using the 3-W method.
HostB: The what, where, and when, right? Like, what wasn't achieved, where mistakes happened, and if the timing was off.
HostA: Exactly. And then there's the communication part. You have to be really strategic about who you tell about the project's closure.
HostB: Yeah, like, not every single stakeholder needs a detailed report, especially for something like a final marketing plan or an app. But an angry customer who gets no notification? That’s a nightmare scenario.
HostA: For sure. So building that communication strategy is key, but only if there's a publicity requirement. It doesn't include partners otherwise.
HostB: And then, you know, the text suggests presenting your achievements, maybe at a small private dinner with stakeholders.
HostA: Though these days, with the pandemic, online B2B presentations have really taken off as the most effective tool.
HostB: But it warns against using professional pages like LinkedIn or ResearchGate to store your results. You gotta use proper databases instead.
HostA: And then finally, the post-project evaluation. It says post-mortems aren't that important unless the project was extremely long.
HostB: I found that part interesting—it says to celebrate the closure with a meeting, but then focus on the negatives, the darkest side of the experience.
HostA: Yeah, quoting Dwight Eisenhower, that optimism never won any battle. So you analyze what went wrong before even thinking about future projects.
HostB: It’s a pretty pragmatic, almost pessimistic approach to wrapping things up.
HostA: But maybe that’s what it takes to actually finish strong and learn from it.
